General course objectives:
General course objectives
This course covers both theory and practical techniques to analyze nonlinear oscillators, networks of complex systems, problems in space and time with applications in science and engineering . Whereas the focus in the introductory level dynamical systems course (01617) lies on the mathematical theory of local dynamics, we focus in this course on mastering the mathematical analysis applied to practical problems occurring in mathematics, physics, engineering, and life sciences. Students will learn to master the analysis, both mathematical and numerical, of dynamical systems exhibiting both simpel and complex behavior.
Learning objectives:
A student who has met the objectives of the course will be able to:
Derive and analyse nonlinear models for physical and biological problems.
Apply basic bifurcation theory.
Use regular perturbation analysis and multi scale analysis
Formulate relevant optimisation models as variational problems, and analyse the associated Euler-Lagrange equations.
Determine solitary and soliton wave solutions to spatial problems (nonlinear partial differential equations), and examine pattern formation in such systems.
Apply separation of time scales in simplification of dynamical models and determine the underlying assumptions and limitations.
Apply modelling to biological systems, in particular to functional feedback systems and reaction-diffusion models.
Apply modelling to population dynamics, in particular to spread of diseases (SIR models).
Content: Theory of nonlinear oscillations, perturbation methods, averaging theory, multi-scale methods, Hamiltonian and Lagrangian theory, dynamics on and of networks, and spatio-temporal dynamics. Applications of bifurcation theory.
